bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861-65.)

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: shot fractures of the pelvic bones
ball entered through the skin over the liver, passed obliquely downward and backward through the ilium

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, identified keyword terms
checked OCR; added minimal mark-up for personal names, place names, and dates

body.p: CASE 622.—Musician J. Dalley, Co. H, 53d Pennsylvania, aged 28 years, was wounded at Fredericksburg, December 13, 1862. He was treated in the field, and at Armory Square Hospital, Washington, and was discharged from service March 6, 1863. The certificate of disability, signed by Surgeon D. W. Bliss, U.S.V., states that there was a "gunshot wound of the left side; the ball entered through the skin over the liver, passed obliquely downward and backward through the ilium, two inches below the crest. Necrosis of ilium." Dalley was pensioned, and was paid to March 4, 1869, when his pension was discontinued.
